title: Feline
data:
The **feline**, usually short for **cat or other feline**, is a [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, and is represented by the lowercase [f](/wiki/F "F") glyph (f). Cats and felines are designated internally by the macro `S_FELINE`.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

The class contains the following monsters:[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

- f [kitten](/wiki/Kitten "Kitten")
- f [housecat](/wiki/Housecat "Housecat")
- f [jaguar](/wiki/Jaguar "Jaguar")
- f [lynx](/wiki/Lynx "Lynx")
- f [panther](/wiki/Panther "Panther")
- f [large cat](/wiki/Large_cat "Large cat")
- f [tiger](/wiki/Tiger "Tiger")

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The [displacer beast](/wiki/Displacer_beast "Displacer beast"), f, is added to the monster class.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Common traits](#Common_traits)
  - [1.1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [4.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [4.4 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [4.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [4.6 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)
  - [4.7 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [5 References](#References)

## Common traits

Felines are quadrupedal and [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") [animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal"); they lack [hands](/wiki/Hands "Hands"), and are visible via [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"). Felines are all of [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment"), and can be separated into two categories:

- [Domestic](/wiki/Domestic "Domestic") felines: the kitten, housecat and large cat
- Wild felines, or "big cats": the jaguar, lynx, panther, and tiger

Felines primarily attack via bites, and the wild felines also have claw attacks. [Chatting](/wiki/Chatting "Chatting") to a tame domestic feline monster can be used to gauge its current condition.

Felines that eat [mimic](/wiki/Mimic "Mimic") corpses may assume the form of a [tripe ration](/wiki/Tripe_ration "Tripe ration") for the duration of the meal if they do not assume a monster-specific form.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

All felines have [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision").

### Generation

Randomly generated felines that are not domestic are always created hostile; domestic felines are sometimes peaceful towards neutral characters.

## Strategy

Most felines have high movement [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed"), allowing them to deal surprising amounts of damage to an unprepared [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") in the early game.

## History

The feline monster class is introduced in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"), which adds the kitten, housecat and large cat and moves the jaguar to the monster class. The jaguar first appears in Hack 1.21 (based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack")), where it uses the J glyph; from Hack for PDP-11 and [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0") to [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e"), it uses the j glyph, and NetHack 3.0.0 gives the monster its current glyph.

The tiger is added to the monster class in [NetHack 3.0.6](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.6 "NetHack 3.0.6"). The panther originates in [NetHack-- 3.1.3](/wiki/NetHack--_3.1.3 "NetHack-- 3.1.3"), while the lynx originates in [SLASH 6](/wiki/SLASH_6 "SLASH 6"), and both monsters make their vanilla debut in [NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0").

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") adds several monsters to the monster class:

- @ / f [werepanther](/wiki/Werepanther "Werepanther")
- f [kamadan](/wiki/Kamadan "Kamadan")
- f [displacer beast](/wiki/Displacer_beast "Displacer beast")
- f [caterwaul](/wiki/Caterwaul "Caterwaul")
- @ / f [weretiger](/wiki/Weretiger "Weretiger")
- f [sabre-toothed cat](/wiki/Sabre-toothed_cat "Sabre-toothed cat")
- f [hellcat](/wiki/Hellcat "Hellcat")

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), the feline is the second [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster class for [Cavepeople](/wiki/Cavepeople "Cavepeople"), and makes up 6⁄175 (3%) of the monsters randomly generated on the [Caveman quest](/wiki/Caveman_quest "Caveman quest").

### dNetHack

[dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack") add several monsters to the monster class:

- f [manticore](/wiki/Manticore_\(dNetHack\) "Manticore (dNetHack)")
- f [serpent-necked lioness](/wiki/Serpent-necked_lioness "Serpent-necked lioness")
- f [displacer beast](/index.php?title=Displacer_beast_\(dNetHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Displacer beast (dNetHack) (page does not exist)")
- f [son of Typhon](/wiki/Son_of_Typhon "Son of Typhon")
- f [hellcat](/index.php?title=Hellcat_\(dNetHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Hellcat (dNetHack) (page does not exist)")
- f [saber-toothed cat](/index.php?title=Saber-toothed_cat_\(dNetHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Saber-toothed cat (dNetHack) (page does not exist)")

The [Cartouche of the Cat Lord](/wiki/User:Chris/dNetHack/Cartouche_of_the_Cat_Lord "User:Chris/dNetHack/Cartouche of the Cat Lord") is a [ward](/wiki/Ward_\(dNetHack\) "Ward (dNetHack)") that can pacify hostile felines that see it, returning them to full health if successful. The [Toustefna](/wiki/User:Chris/dNetHack/Toustefna "User:Chris/dNetHack/Toustefna") is a ward that can scare off felines.

### SpliceHack

[SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack") adds several monsters to the monster class:

- f [serval](/index.php?title=Serval\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Serval (page does not exist)")
- @ / f [weretiger](/wiki/Weretiger "Weretiger")
- f [serpopard](/index.php?title=Serpopard_\(SpliceHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Serpopard (SpliceHack) (page does not exist)")
- f [lion](/index.php?title=Lion\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Lion (page does not exist)")
- f [fat cat](/wiki/Fat_cat "Fat cat")
- f [displacer beast](/wiki/Displacer_beast "Displacer beast")
- f [hellcat](/wiki/Hellcat "Hellcat")

A [pinch of catnip](/wiki/Pinch_of_catnip "Pinch of catnip") thrown at any feline will tame and [confuse](/wiki/Confuse "Confuse") them, and a hero eating catnip while in the form of a feline will be confused for 2d8 (more) turns.

### EvilHack

[EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") adds two monsters to the monster class:

- f [saber-toothed tiger](/wiki/Saber-toothed_tiger "Saber-toothed tiger")
- f [displacer beast](/wiki/Displacer_beast "Displacer beast")

### SlashTHEM

[SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") retains the monsters added in SLASH'EM, and adds two monsters to the monster class:

- f [algolian suntiger](/index.php?title=Algolian_suntiger\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Algolian suntiger (page does not exist)")
- f [sphinx](/wiki/Sphinx "Sphinx")

The feline is the first quest monster class for [Zookeepers](/wiki/Zookeeper "Zookeeper"), and makes up 24⁄175 (14%) of the monsters randomly generated on the [Zookeeper quest](/index.php?title=Zookeeper_quest\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Zookeeper quest (page does not exist)"). The feline is also the second quest monster class for Cavepeople as in UnNetHack, and makes up 6⁄175 (3%) of the monsters randomly generated on the Caveman quest.

[Liontamer](/index.php?title=Liontamer\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Liontamer (page does not exist)") is an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") bullwhip that deals extra damage against felines.

### Hack'EM

[Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM") adds several monsters to the monster class, including many from other variants:

- f [serval](/index.php?title=Serval\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Serval (page does not exist)")
- f [caterwaul](/wiki/Caterwaul "Caterwaul")
- @ / f [werepanther](/wiki/Werepanther "Werepanther")
- @ / f [weretiger](/wiki/Weretiger "Weretiger")
- f [saber-toothed cat](/index.php?title=Saber-toothed_cat_\(Hack%27EM\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Saber-toothed cat (Hack'EM) (page does not exist)")
- f [lion](/index.php?title=Lion\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Lion (page does not exist)")
- f [serpopard](/index.php?title=Serpopard_\(Hack%27EM\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Serpopard (Hack'EM) (page does not exist)")
- f [fat cat](/wiki/Fat_cat "Fat cat")
- f [kamadan](/wiki/Kamadan "Kamadan")
- f [saber-toothed tiger](/index.php?title=Saber-toothed_tiger_\(Hack%27EM\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Saber-toothed tiger (Hack'EM) (page does not exist)")
- f [displacer beast](/wiki/Displacer_beast "Displacer beast")
- f [hellcat](/wiki/Hellcat "Hellcat")

As in SpliceHack, a sprig of catnip thrown at any feline will tame and confuse them, and eating catnip while in the form of a feline will confuse the hero for 2d8 (more) turns.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [include/monsym.h in NetHack 3.6.7, line 20](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/include/monsym.h#L20)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/monst.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 347](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/monst.c#L347)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/dogmove.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1354](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/dogmove.c#L1354)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Feline

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

The feline, usually short for cat or other feline, is a monster class that appears in NetHack, and is represented by the lowercase f glyph (f). Cats and felines are designated internally by the macro S_FELINE.[1]

The class contains the following monsters:[2]

  • f kitten
  • f housecat
  • f jaguar
  • f lynx
  • f panther
  • f large cat
  • f tiger

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

The displacer beast, f, is added to the monster class.

Contents

  • 1 Common traits
    • 1.1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SLASH'EM
    • 4.2 UnNetHack
    • 4.3 dNetHack
    • 4.4 SpliceHack
    • 4.5 EvilHack
    • 4.6 SlashTHEM
    • 4.7 Hack'EM
  • 5 References

Common traits

Felines are quadrupedal and carnivorous animals; they lack hands, and are visible via infravision. Felines are all of neutral alignment, and can be separated into two categories:

  • Domestic felines: the kitten, housecat and large cat
  • Wild felines, or "big cats": the jaguar, lynx, panther, and tiger

Felines primarily attack via bites, and the wild felines also have claw attacks. Chatting to a tame domestic feline monster can be used to gauge its current condition.

Felines that eat mimic corpses may assume the form of a tripe ration for the duration of the meal if they do not assume a monster-specific form.[3]

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

All felines have infravision.

Generation

Randomly generated felines that are not domestic are always created hostile; domestic felines are sometimes peaceful towards neutral characters.

Strategy

Most felines have high movement speed, allowing them to deal surprising amounts of damage to an unprepared hero in the early game.

History

The feline monster class is introduced in NetHack 3.0.0, which adds the kitten, housecat and large cat and moves the jaguar to the monster class. The jaguar first appears in Hack 1.21 (based on Jay Fenlason's Hack), where it uses the J glyph; from Hack for PDP-11 and Hack 1.0 to NetHack 2.3e, it uses the j glyph, and NetHack 3.0.0 gives the monster its current glyph.

The tiger is added to the monster class in NetHack 3.0.6. The panther originates in NetHack-- 3.1.3, while the lynx originates in SLASH 6, and both monsters make their vanilla debut in NetHack 3.3.0.

Variants

SLASH'EM

SLASH'EM adds several monsters to the monster class:

  • @ / f werepanther
  • f kamadan
  • f displacer beast
  • f caterwaul
  • @ / f weretiger
  • f sabre-toothed cat
  • f hellcat

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, the feline is the second quest monster class for Cavepeople, and makes up 6⁄175 (3%) of the monsters randomly generated on the Caveman quest.

dNetHack

dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack add several monsters to the monster class:

  • f manticore
  • f serpent-necked lioness
  • f displacer beast
  • f son of Typhon
  • f hellcat
  • f saber-toothed cat

The Cartouche of the Cat Lord is a ward that can pacify hostile felines that see it, returning them to full health if successful. The Toustefna is a ward that can scare off felines.

SpliceHack

SpliceHack adds several monsters to the monster class:

  • f serval
  • @ / f weretiger
  • f serpopard
  • f lion
  • f fat cat
  • f displacer beast
  • f hellcat

A pinch of catnip thrown at any feline will tame and confuse them, and a hero eating catnip while in the form of a feline will be confused for 2d8 (more) turns.

EvilHack

EvilHack adds two monsters to the monster class:

  • f saber-toothed tiger
  • f displacer beast

SlashTHEM

SlashTHEM retains the monsters added in SLASH'EM, and adds two monsters to the monster class:

  • f algolian suntiger
  • f sphinx

The feline is the first quest monster class for Zookeepers, and makes up 24⁄175 (14%) of the monsters randomly generated on the Zookeeper quest. The feline is also the second quest monster class for Cavepeople as in UnNetHack, and makes up 6⁄175 (3%) of the monsters randomly generated on the Caveman quest.

Liontamer is an artifact bullwhip that deals extra damage against felines.

Hack'EM

Hack'EM adds several monsters to the monster class, including many from other variants:

  • f serval
  • f caterwaul
  • @ / f werepanther
  • @ / f weretiger
  • f saber-toothed cat
  • f lion
  • f serpopard
  • f fat cat
  • f kamadan
  • f saber-toothed tiger
  • f displacer beast
  • f hellcat

As in SpliceHack, a sprig of catnip thrown at any feline will tame and confuse them, and eating catnip while in the form of a feline will confuse the hero for 2d8 (more) turns.

References

  1. ↑ include/monsym.h in NetHack 3.6.7, line 20
  2. ↑ src/monst.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 347
  3. ↑ src/dogmove.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1354
